nytimes_articles.headline: The Battle to Lure Asian Gamblers
nytimes_articles.abstract:
PAUL LIU spends every Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday in New York City's Chinatown visiting restaurants, clubs and businesses. His mission: to recruit players for the Trump Taj Mahal casino here.

Mr. Liu, who is vice president of international marketing for the casino, is part of a small army of executives and representatives from this city's dozen casinos that compete, in this country and abroad, for the Asian market. About 80 percent of these players are Chinese; the rest are Korean, Japanese and Thai.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sarah Huffman, John H. Griffin
nytimes_articles.abstract: Sarah Elizabeth Huffman, the daughter of Sue B. Huffman-Robison of Englewood, N.J., and Dr. William H. Huffman of Charlotte, N.C., was married yesterday to John Henry Griffin, a son of Antonia Allegra of St. Helena, Calif., and Dr. John H. Griffin of Del Mar, Calif. The Rev. Jon Huber, a Universal Life minister, performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. William Jaeger in St. Helena.   Mrs. Griffin, 26, is an assistant director of Learning Strategies, an educational concern in Pacifica, Calif. She graduated from Brown University and received a master's degree in English from Mills College.

nytimes_articles.headline: Barkley Leads Suns To Dreamers' Matchup
nytimes_articles.abstract: Charles Barkley has shoe commercials, a gold medal, golf clubs and a house with elevators -- everything Michael Jordan has. Now, he wants Jordan's ring.   This afternoon, Barkley got a second wind, got in Shawn Kemp's way and got the Phoenix Suns into the National Basketball Association Championship series. Because of a rousing 123-110 victory over the Seattle SuperSonics in Game 7 of the Western Conference finals, Barkley and Jordan will finally rub elbows and cleanshaven heads and play for the Chicago Bulls' league title, starting here Wednesday.

nytimes_articles.headline: In the Region: Connecticut; When Rivers Run Amok, Who's at Fault?
nytimes_articles.abstract: AT 5:30 A.M. last June 6 Laura and Richard Raynor were awakened in their second-floor bedroom by frantic phone calls from neighbors telling them to get out of the house before the Quinnipiac River rose any higher than the ground floor.   One neighbor had been awakened by strange noises from the furnace and realized that Garden Road, a new street of neat, year-old houses about 75 feet from the river, was under water.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Man to Call When a Lion or a Tiger Breaks a Tooth
nytimes_articles.abstract:
DR. EDWARD V. SHAGAM has performed root-canal work on an Exxon tiger, has been up to his shoulder in elephant spit and was nearly nudged off a catwalk while examining the teeth of a giraffe that wanted him to scratch the top of her head.

He has applied braces to an English springer spaniel show dog, extracted a breeder rabbit's troublesome extra tooth and mended the mouth of a $4,000 imported German guard dog that wouldn't bite anything because he broke a tooth on the trip to the United States.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Noteworthy Collection
nytimes_articles.abstract: This selection of paperbacks is from the New & Noteworthy column since the 1992 Christmas issue. ALIEN INK: The F.B.I.'s War on Freedom of Expression By Natalie Robins. Rutgers University, $14.95. J. Edgar Hoover's investigation of American writers.

nytimes_articles.headline: TRANSACTIONS
nytimes_articles.abstract: Baseball American League  KANSAS CITY ROYALS -- Placed Keith Miller, infielder, on the 15-day disabled list. Recalled Craig Wilson, infielder, from Omaha of the American Association.

nytimes_articles.headline: When Recipes Are Not Recipes, but Ideas
nytimes_articles.abstract: OVER the years, among the many major culinary trends, two polar-opposite positions have evolved in the recipe-writing business. One sort of food writer assumes that the cook wants and needs to be told what to do in a prescriptive fashion -- make it work, make it beautiful. But from the opposite camp come recipes aimed at some presumably smaller number of cooks who are confident enough and experienced enough to search out the cooking tutors who will simply show them the way and set them free.   Elizabeth David, the British food writer, was renowned for being a cookbook author in the latter camp (the American chef Anne Rosenzweig once said of David's writing: "Recipes were not recipes; they were ideas"). More recently, there have been many other strong examples of the approach. Among contemporary books, Shirley King's "Fish: The Basics" comes to mind for its willingness to give direction and then trust the cook to do something with it.

nytimes_articles.headline:
TRAVEL;
Arcadia: Last of the Head Trips
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THE travel book, like the novel, is a literary genre apparently without rules. Fourteen lines are mandatory in a sonnet, and a tragedy must end with someone's death, but the travel book is free from precept or precedent: it needs only to describe a journey, which writing -- as the movement of language through time -- automatically does. Nevertheless, the best travel books owe a secret allegiance to one of the most ancient literary genres: they all turn out to be versions of pastoral.

Pastoral is the form that depicts the paradise we have lost, the rustic simplicity of a good life in a golden age. The pastoral ideal of the classical poets, from Theocritus to Sir Philip Sidney, was irretrievably distant in time. For the travel writer, the idyll is teasingly remote in space, but can be reached by consulting the airline schedules.

nytimes_articles.headline: Brown Is Late at Start But Early at the Finish
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Brown crew, the men's varsity eight that had hardly been tested this season, was a little casual and a little tardy in reaching the starting line today for the championship race of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta on the Cooper River course.   And when the 2,000-meter race began, the boat from the University of Pennsylvania, Brown's foremost rival this spring, jumped into the lead and by 500 meters was almost a boat length ahead. But then the Bears bore down, with 20 strokes of extra power.

nytimes_articles.headline: Katherine Kamhi, Tony Coghlan
nytimes_articles.abstract: TONY COGHLAN and Katherine Kamhi met two years ago in one of the most hard-core aerobics classes in New York City: Fernanda's class, as it's known, at the Jeff Martin Studio on West 76th Street.    "It's the class from hell," Mr. Coghlan said. "The instructor's name is Fernanda Chandoha. She is like a Marine drill sergeant. She does not let you take it easy. She knows everyone by name, so that saves you asking people's names because you hear them shouted out during the class."

nytimes_articles.headline: A la Carte; The Cafe Is New, but Its Name Rings a Familiar Bell
nytimes_articles.abstract: A NEW "5 & 10" that has nothing to do with Woolworth's or nickels and dimes has opened in Port Washington. The 5 & 10 Cafe, at 14 Haven Avenue (883-0303), charges $5 for all appetizers, pizzas, burgers, pasta starters and desserts with coffee. Main courses are $10.   This vast multilevel Italian cafe with an open kitchen, brick pizza oven and bare floors and tables was a busy, bustling, upbeat place on a recent visit. It is whimsically decorated with toy airplanes, tricycles, baby carriages and rocking horses hanging overhead. Signs from bygone days proclaiming the virtues of items like penny candy and Hershey's Kisses, circa 1930's, dot the walls.

nytimes_articles.headline: IN THE NATURAL STATE
nytimes_articles.abstract:
IN the attic I could hear Linda rummaging through our camping gear, and I could sense her exasperation. It had been several years and one house move since we'd been on a road trip. Tents and sleeping bags burrow their way to the bottom of piles with less provocation than this.

Our dog, Moose, was standing in the door, edgy as a cat. He had seen these preparations before and knew that fate hung in the balance for him -- a summer of fun or weeks nursing his loss in the kennel. He had no way of knowing that it would not be the former, and I had no way of easing his burden.

nytimes_articles.headline: 'This Town Will Die Without Our School'
nytimes_articles.abstract: THIS Union County borough is a self-contained place. Most of its 7,574 residents are employed nearby and shop in the strip of stores along Kenilworth Boulevard. "It's the kind of town where you're born, you go to school, get married, raise a family and die," said Janet Glynos, a Kenilworth native.    Now, forces inside and outside the community have combined to endanger its way of life. Since 1970, the population has declined by almost 1,600 people. A new shopping center and supermarket are going up on one end of town, threatening the downtown businesses. And David Brearley Regional High School, which Charles Vitale, a former school board president, calls "the social and civic hub of the town," is scheduled to be closed at the end of the 1993 school year.

nytimes_articles.headline: Book Review/Section 7
nytimes_articles.abstract: In the Summer Reading issue, Thomas Pynchon kicks off a series of essays on the seven deadly sins with a reflection on his favorite -- sloth. John Mortimer reviews Scott Turow's latest, "Pleading Guilty," and Camille Paglia examines a new biography of Judy Garland. Elmore Leonard, Germaine Greer, Grace Paley, Matt Groening and Dr. Ruth Westheimer talk of their first encounters with forbidden books. Plus seasonal roundups for cooks, travelers and gardeners, and a list of vacation reading.

nytimes_articles.headline: Keeping the Faith When Faiths Differ
nytimes_articles.abstract:
WHEN Nobu and Flora Asano's son was 4 someone asked the boy, "What are you?" 

He answered, "I'm half Italian, half Japanese and all American."

His mother was born in Italy, the niece of a monsignor in the Roman Catholic Church, and his father was born in Japan of a Buddhist family.

nytimes_articles.headline: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
nytimes_articles.abstract:
SEAFOOD FESTIVALS

The role of seafood as a staple for early settlers of the state and as an important industry today will be celebrated on Saturday and next Sunday in Atlantic City and Belmar.

nytimes_articles.headline: Eric M. Dessen and Florence J. Kamil
nytimes_articles.abstract: Dr. and Mrs. Richard S. Kamil of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Florence Jody Kamil, to Eric Michael Dessen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley B. Dessen of East Hills, L.I. A fall wedding is planned.   Ms. Kamil is the buyer for designer ladies shoes for Bloomingdale's, the department store, in New York. She graduated from the University of Michigan. Her father is an orthopedic surgeon in West Bloomfield, Mich.

nytimes_articles.headline: Harkes, Accent and All, Back for Tourney
nytimes_articles.abstract: John Harkes, the pride of Kearny, N.J., rejoined the United States national soccer team this week to resuscitate his old mates in the U.S. Cup '93 opener today against Brazil in New Haven.   Fresh from Britain, where he played a rangy midfield for Sheffield Wednesday of England's Premier League, Harkes was strangely disconnected from his American teammates at a reunion dinner at Liberty State Park in Jersey City, N.J., last Wednesday. He spoke with a thick English accent. He sported a neo-Old World haircut. Harkes even strutted, somehow, like a British soccer player.

nytimes_articles.headline: Delta Air Awards For Gay Partners
nytimes_articles.abstract: Delta Air Lines has changed the rules of its frequent flier program to make it easier for legally certified gay partners to transfer awards to each other. Until now, Delta had allowed its frequent flier customers to transfer their awards -- typically tickets earned by flying a designated number of miles -- only to family members, which Delta defines as spouse, child, parent, siblings, grandparent, grandchild, in-laws, step children and step-siblings. .   Of the seven major domestic carriers, Delta, along with T.W.A., had the most restrictive policies regarding award transfers. The other five -- USAir, United, American, Northwest and Continental -- allow frequent fliers to assign their awards to anyone they choose, regardless of relationship.

nytimes_articles.headline: Can We Really Read With Our Ears? The 'Wuthering' Truth About Novels on Tape
nytimes_articles.abstract: ONE Saturday in the early 1980's, in Chevy Chase, Md., I spied George F. Will trucking along the sidewalk, wearing a Walkman. It was a minor thrill, catching the icon of conservatism in a secret weekend tryst with pop culture -- who knew, maybe even with rock-and-roll! -- but, alas, it proved short-lived. A few weeks later, I read somewhere that the columnist wasn't using his Walkman for music at all, but for something I'd never heard of -- books on tape. He went through a book a week, Mr. Will noted, "using time otherwise wasted in taxis, shaving or walking."   Maybe it was the vision of George Will shaving his way through all 12 volumes of Anthony Powell's "Dance to the Music of Time" that scared me off. In any case, 10 long years passed before I took the leap into aural literature. One afternoon last summer, I found myself standing before a state-of-the-art taped bookshelf -- everything from Thomas Hardy to Thomas Harris -- in that bibliophile's paradise in Ann Arbor, Mich., Borders Book Shop. A long drive was behind me and a longer one ahead, with the same two dozen cassettes playing the same music over and over. Somewhat later I got into my car and, heading east for Lake Erie and Canada, ejected the Smiths from the tape deck and popped in Robert Stone's "Outer bridge Reach."

nytimes_articles.headline: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THE TIME IS RIPE

More than 100 exhibitors will be on hand today for a free consumer exposition of "fun, information and self-help" for "mature" citizens, of whom Long Island has many.

nytimes_articles.headline: Elvis Is Back, Why Not Daddy?
nytimes_articles.abstract:
RUMORS FROM THE LOST WORLD
By Alan Davis.
112 pp. Minneapolis:
New Rivers Press/The Talman Company.
Paper, $9.95.

nytimes_articles.headline: Interpreting Squiggles 'As Written'
nytimes_articles.abstract: An eminent pianist playing at Merkin Concert Hall late last year did exactly what Beethoven asked him to do and may have ended up doing what Beethoven did not want. Another eminent pianist playing at Carnegie Hall last month may have violated Beethoven's wishes but fulfilled his intentions. With Toscanini's sharp imperative -- "come scritto" ("as written") -- ringing in our ears, what can it all mean?   Pianist No. 1 was Robert Taub, pianist No. 2 Alfred Brendel; the object of their attentions, the "Waldstein" Sonata. Like his contemporaries, Beethoven often turned pedaling over to the performer's good sense, but there are places in which the manuscripts give strict guidance to feet as well as to hands. One is the last movement of the "Waldstein," where for eight measures at a time Beethoven asks that the foot push down the right-hand pedal, free the strings to vibrate unencumbered and so allow sounds to gather in a heap.

nytimes_articles.headline: Swimming Pools and the Environment
nytimes_articles.abstract: HARDLY anything is more sybaritic than floating in a swimming pool 20 or 30 or even 40 yards from Long Island Sound, but since March 10 that pleasure has been sharply curtailed for waterfront residents of the village of Larchmont, the town and village of Mamaroneck and the city of Rye.   Under the State Department of Environmental Conservation's regulation of Coastal Erosion Hazard Areas, the construction of swimming pools on the grounds of houses in the Coastal Erosion Hazard Area of the four communities will no longer be possible. "It is because pools, more than any other structures, will increase the erosion action, because pools are so heavy," said Patrick L. Ferracane, water-program specialist with the State Department of Environmental Conservation for Region 3 in Tarrytown, which includes Westchester.

nytimes_articles.headline: Orff: Two Second Thoughts
nytimes_articles.abstract: If ever a composer could be said to have fallen out of favor, it is Carl Orff. His flamboyant scenic cantata "Carmina Burana" is occasionally performed on pops programs or by ballet companies. His educational ideas, usually adulterated by the Kodaly method or another pedagogical approach, are still applied in schools. But of the considerable breadth of his achievement, there is little representation.   So the budget reissue of the sole studio recording of Orff's quasi-opera "Antigonae" (Deutsche Grammophon 437 721-2; three CD's) is of particular interest. Now available by import and set for American release later this year, it can be profitably compared with a newly released historical album of the 1949 world premiere at the Salzburg Festival (Stradivarius STR 10060; two CD's).

nytimes_articles.headline: Bringing Dinos Back to Life
nytimes_articles.abstract: WHAT EXACTLY ARE YOU seeing when a triceratops or a velociraptor appears on screen in "Jurassic Park"? For close-ups, the film makers often used full-size robots by the model-maker Stan Winston. When the dinosaurs are in motion, however, viewers will probably be looking at computer animation.   The animation took place at Industrial Light and Magic, the California special-effects house. The company, which has also handled special effects for "The Abyss" and "Terminator 2: Judgment Day," used the dinosaur robots designed by Mr. Winston (such as the seven-foot velociraptors pictured here) as guides. The animation alone took 18 months. Meanwhile, other technicians blocked out the actions of the invisible dinosaurs on the movie set.

nytimes_articles.headline: Eastham, Cape Cod's Little Secret
nytimes_articles.abstract: HALFWAY between the elbow and knuckles of Cape Cod, Massachusetts' long arm flexing into the Atlantic, lies a little town that most vacationers hardly notice. "You can pass through the village centers of Eastham and North Eastham and never know you've been there," notes one guidebook. And it's almost true. Bisected by Route 6, Cape Cod's main artery, Eastham appears at first glance to have little of even passing interest, besides a glimpse of water and a vaguely hat-shaped visitor center. To most hurried visitors, "the gateway" to the National Seashore, as Eastham is known, remains a stop for gas on the way to the beach; for those who pause a moment longer on their way to Wellfleet or Provincetown, it's a straggle of efficiency cottages, a few motels and a handful of slightly faded roadside attractions. No blown glass, no band concerts, no yacht club.    But for those who linger, Eastham provides its own quiet blandishments. The sun rises over the ocean on one edge of town, and sets a few miles away over Cape Cod Bay. In between sunrise and sunset, you can swim across a couple of freshwater ponds, or brood by a salt marsh. A watery, drifting place, Eastham loses a bit of itself every year to the tides, shored up only by beach grass and scrub pine. Where the ground isn't spongy, it's sandy. Long ago, I decided that this tentative quality must be why Eastham has stayed so unassuming, blessedly free of choked harbors, of restaurants that treat lobster as haute cuisine, of golf courses larger than half an acre. Instead it's a mom-and-pop kind of town; the same family has always owned the general store, and a rented bicycle comes with a desultory chat about back roads, and a reminder to wear a helmet. When you spot someone wearing Spandex on the bike path, you know he's ridden in from somewhere else.

nytimes_articles.headline: Brown, a Free Agent, Wants to Stay Put
nytimes_articles.abstract: Bengals wide receiver EDDIE BROWN, just granted free-agent status, says he'll consider remaining in Cincinnati.   "Cincinnati is still in my heart," Brown said Friday after an arbitrator made him a free agent, ruling that an injury to his neck was football-related.

nytimes_articles.headline: Car Aromas Fit for a King
nytimes_articles.abstract: WHAT: A 5-inch-high, 3 1/2-inch wide, gold-painted plastic air freshener in the shape of an eight-pointed crown topped with a cross. Its dome comes in six colors: blue, black, red, green, white and a regal purple. On the smog-hazed streets of inner-urban America, where they are wildly popular, the Crown Freshner (the manufacturer's spelling), which weighs about seven ounces, is called simply the King.

nytimes_articles.headline: Israel Is Seeking to Ease Law On Divorce in Rabbis' Courts
nytimes_articles.abstract: The details get obscure, but to cut through the thicket:   Miri Nahadar entered marriage in Iran when she was only 15, and had two children, who are now 22 and 17. She emigrated to Israel with other Iranian Jews after the ayatollahs took power in 1979, found her husband unwilling to hang around for more than 5 minutes at a time and finally decided, 10 years ago, that she wanted nothing more from life than a divorce.

nytimes_articles.headline: In Sarajevo, War Also Means Battles of the Sexes
nytimes_articles.abstract: With her food store and home reduced to rubble, her city besieged and her nation uprooted, Jasna Delalic picked the darkest days of Bosnia's war to become a single mother. Despite constant shelling, food and water queues and deep uncertainty about the future, Mrs. Delalic has filed for divorce from her 33-year-old husband because he refused to fight the nationalist Serbs attacking Sarajevo.   "I hate cowards," said the jobless, 30-year-old Muslim woman, who now lugs her food-aid packages back to a one-room apartment she shares with her two grade-school-age daughters and another single woman. "He was supposed to stay on the front line, but he wounded himself in the leg with an automatic."

nytimes_articles.headline: POSTINGS: Mount Morris Bank; Guaranteeing Integrity For a Harlem Landmark
nytimes_articles.abstract: Acknowledging that the 110-year-old Mount Morris Bank Building at Park Avenue and 125th Street had suffered more than a decade as a vacant hulk, the Landmarks Preservation Commission designated it anyway last January, saying that it had kept its "architectural integrity to a surprisingly high degree."   But before she would vote to sustain the landmark designation, Councilwoman C. Virginia Fields wanted assurances that the city, which has owned the building since 1972, would insure its physical survival until a buyer or new use could be found. Most urgent, she said, was the closing of the open roof and windows.

nytimes_articles.headline: Groom Patrol
nytimes_articles.abstract: Weed, weed, weed, and thin, thin, thin. These two chores are unfortunately the key to growing hefty plants that have enough nutrients and space to grow. As you're weeding, keep an eye out for annuals that have self-seeded that you may want to save. Last week, I found lots of dill and cleome, which I moved to other parts of the garden.   Some hardy annuals likely to seed themselves are calendula, bachelor's button, cosmos, nicotiana, larkspur and forget-me-nots. So if you have them in the garden, don't cut off all their spent blossoms this summer. Let some go to seed. Then mulch the area before the ground freezes, and in the spring, see what comes up.

nytimes_articles.headline: Lyme Center Expands Its Hours
nytimes_articles.abstract: TO treat the more than 3,000 new cases of Lyme disease expected in Westchester this year and head off the debilitating complications that often accompany the later stages of the illness, the County Medical Center here has expanded the hours of its Lyme Disease Diagnostic Center.   Since the center opened four years ago, it has evaluated more than 7,000 county residents who suspected they had contracted Lyme disease, with more than half testing positive, said Dr. Gary P. Wormser, the center's director.

nytimes_articles.headline: The New-Politics Myth
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Lani Guinier embarrassment may end a central myth of the Administration -- that President Clinton would usher in an age of New Politics, with divisive choices of left and right merging in happy consensus.    News analysis, page 26.

nytimes_articles.headline: Son of Best Seller Stalks the Moors
nytimes_articles.abstract: The book business, which hardly used to be a business at all, has in the last 10 years begun to search for The Next Big Thing with a zeal once found only in the movie business. And what is The Next Big Thing in the book biz? Oh honey-chickie-baby, have I got an answer for you. Ready? O.K.: Sequel rights. Did you get it? Good.

nytimes_articles.headline: From the Ancient To the Experimental
nytimes_articles.abstract: THIS week and the next will be busy ones for New York numismatists. Three companies have scheduled auctions, and Sotheby's starts the whirl on Thursday with its auction of United States and foreign coins. The offerings include a Brilliant Proof 1879 Flowing Hair Stella, a $4 gold piece.    Stellas are among the rarest of the experimental United States coins, with only about 25 of the original Flowing Hair variety struck. Another 400 were struck later, but to date there is no way to tell the originals from the restrikes.

nytimes_articles.headline: Who Dares Bash a Condom?
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   I was nothing less than horrified to read Elizabeth Kaye's article on the Reality female condom. Besides being cute, which was apparently her overriding goal, she succeeded at doing a tremendous disservice to women. Undone by her own denial of the risks women face through sex, and her own obvious discomfort with women's touching their own genitals, she's become part of the "female-condom bashing chic." Why, she even bashes male condoms!

nytimes_articles.headline: Tracy Anbinder And Robert Baron
nytimes_articles.abstract: Tracy Jennifer Anbinder, the daughter of Stephen and Madeline Anbinder of New York, was married last evening to Robert Andrew Baron, a son of Alvin and Gloria Baron of North Woodmere, L.I. Rabbi Joel Y. Zion officiated at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park.   Ms. Anbinder, 28, is keeping her name. She is a law student at the University of Pennsylvania. She graduated magna cum laude from Duke University, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa.

nytimes_articles.headline: An Appreciation Of 'Mothers' on Stage
nytimes_articles.abstract: To read Alvin Klein's recent review of "Mothers," at the Crossroads Theater, made me believe that the play was a dull, outlandish and obvious vehicle -- a play that not only could but should be overlooked.   How far from the truth (both dramatic and emotional) can you get?   With trepidation, I went to see the production. Not only did I see it, I felt it as well. My own emotions as a human being were stirred. As a theater person, I may be a bit more critical than others, but the performances, the play, the interplay of past and present, of ritual and reality, of customs both East and West, thoroughly overtook me.

nytimes_articles.headline: Baskets to Tickle The Imagination
nytimes_articles.abstract:
EVERY time the Brown-Grotta Gallery on Grumman Hill Road in Wilton creates a new exhibition, they redecorate. In the art-in-use gallery -- which takes over the entire Colonial farmhouse of Tom Grotta, a fine arts photographer and advertising agency owner, and his wife, Rhonda Brown, a lawyer -- the upstairs has been shifted to make room for a nursery. 

The couple have commissioned a basket-bassinet from Sharon and Leon Niehues for the baby, a tapestry to go behind it by Mariette Rousseau-Vermette and a mobile by William Accorsi, Mr. Grotta said. Sofas, like chameleons, have changed color throughout the house and a new long white desk has appeared in the master bedroom to herald baskets for the current exhibition "Divergent Views: The Basketwork of Gyongy Laky and Sharon and Leon Niehues," on view through July 11.

nytimes_articles.headline:
MUSIC;
Summerfest: Something for Everyone . . .
nytimes_articles.abstract:
RUTGERS SUMMERFEST 1993, an eight-week festival of the arts with the theme "The Stories That Bind Us," will encourage its audiences to examine some of their assumptions and stereotypes about the arts and to expand their esthetic horizons.

The festival is presented by the Mason Gross School of the Arts at Rutgers. The theme, said Lance Olson, assistant dean of arts programming at the school, is intended to be explored in its double meaning -- "those stories that brought us together, and stories that restrict the way we can understand our world." The summer program will also have several subthemes.

nytimes_articles.headline: Your Home: Housing Trusts; Protecting The Equity In a Home
nytimes_articles.abstract: WHEN it comes to protecting the equity in your home for the benefit of the next generation, a trust has been traditionally viewed as the estate planning vehicle of choice.    Until recently it served primarily the well-to-do because its aim was to sidestep both state and Federal estate taxes. And since the owner's total assets -- the home plus any other holdings, such as stocks, mutual funds or bonds -- had to exceed $600,000 before the more hefty Federal estate taxes were due, it became a meaningless exercise for people of more modest means.

nytimes_articles.headline: Lugano
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Italian spoken by Lugano's residents, the pasta and pizza on the outdoor cafe tables and the campaniles of the churches evoke the Mediterranean. At the same time, Lugano, the cultural and business center of Switzerland's Ticino Canton, offers Swiss tidiness and calm, rather than the exuberance and bustle of Italy itself, which is just 15 miles away.    Two pyramid-shaped hills frame Lugano Bay on five-pronged Lake Lugano, which Switzerland shares with Italy; on jasmine-scented summer evenings, lights twinkle from the many villas, restaurants and cafes on the slopes. The vegetation is subtropical -- palms, cypresses and oleanders, along with hundreds of rose varieties from May through October -- in the Civic Gardens and along the sweeping lakefront.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Empty Embassies
nytimes_articles.abstract: Let's stipulate that President Clinton has a lot on his mind these days besides naming ambassadors. Granted, too, that his choosing of ambassadors is complicated by a laudable desire to give more scope to women and minorities. Add to this the cumbersome F.B.I. clearances that now include the Nannygate hurdle of possible prior employment of illegal domestics.   Even so, none of those factors can excuse the surfeit of empty embassies still sitting in many countries, some of vital importance to American foreign policy. These vacancies attest to the indecision that afflicts a wobbling Presidency.

nytimes_articles.headline: Black Lobby Group to Include Foreign Policy
nytimes_articles.abstract: With a celebration more reminiscent of a movie premiere than a staid research group, TransAfrica, the lobby best known for its anti-apartheid campaign, opened its foreign policy institute here this weekend.   In a city with dozens of research institutes offering intellectual grist for everything from urban policy to the arcana of international affairs, another "think tank" would seem superfluous.

nytimes_articles.headline: Challenge of Replacing Old Foundation Sills
nytimes_articles.abstract: OWNERS of older, neglected or poorly built houses and outbuildings, especially in rural or wet locations, often face the problem of replacing decayed foundation sills, the horizontal beams separating the framing of the building from the foundation walls. Replacing the sills is seldom a job for amateurs, but doing so on a detached garage, shed or small barn makes a challenging, if strenuous, project.   Two helpful books before before starting the job are "Renovating Old Houses" by George Nash (Taunton Press, 1992) and "Renovation: A Complete Guide" by Michael W. Litchfield (Prentice Hall, 1991). A useful article on sills was in The Journal of Light Construction in October. The magazine may be available in libraries, or readers can call (802) 434-4747.

nytimes_articles.headline: Rockies' Pitchers Serve Up Feasts for Batters
nytimes_articles.abstract: It had to appear as simple to the architects of expansion as it did to the architects of the Clinton campaign.   The pitching, stupid. Concentrate on that and that alone and you have a chance to be a representative major league club. Fail to put some semblance of a foundation together, fail to build from the mound out, and you have the Colorado Rockies.

nytimes_articles.headline: Jewish Museum Reopens Sunday
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Jewish Museum, at Fifth Avenue and 92d Street, will reopen next Sunday after a two-and-a-half-year, $36 million renovation and expansion. Founded in 1904, the museum has the largest collection of Jewish art and artifacts in the world outside of Israel.   The museum, which is housed in the 1908 Warburg Mansion, has doubled its exhibition space to 22,000 square feet, added a cafe and enlarged its gift shop.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bach Is on Several Programs Today
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE music of Bach figures prominently in several concerts today. The Master Singers of Westchester under Les Robinson Hadsell will perform the "B minor Mass" at 3 P.M. at the Fox Lane School in Bedford. The number to call for more details is 234-6535.   Also today, at 4 P.M., in Trinity Episcopal Church in Ossining, Don Kerr plays Bach's "G major Fantasy" on the organ and Bach's "French Suite in B minor" on the harpsichord. Two sonatas, Mendelssohn's in C minor for organ, and Mozart's in C major, K. 279, for harpsichord, are also on the program. For further details, the number to call is 941-0806.

nytimes_articles.headline: The 'Busters' Are Bored
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   I have noted with bemusement that rare is the Styles section that does not contain an article about grunge or raves. The boomer fascination with this supposed trend of the baby-bust generation far exceeds any interest which most of us "busters" have in it, and as a result, it has received attention far out of proportion to its actual popularity.

nytimes_articles.headline: REPUBLICAN GAINS TEXAS SENATE SEAT
nytimes_articles.abstract: Kay Bailey Hutchison, the Texas State Treasurer and a Republican, was overwhelmingly elected to the United States Senate today after campaign in which she relentlessly focused on opposition to tax increases proposed by President Clinton.   Mrs. Hutchison, a 49-year-old former state representative, easily defeated Bob Krueger, the Democrat who was appointed to the seat earlier this year by Gov. Ann W. Richards after Lloyd Bentsen resigned to become Treasury Secretary.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Models in Underwear Were Almost Overdressed
nytimes_articles.abstract: There was a lot to see at Calvin Klein's blowout benefit fashion show at the Hollywood Bowl on Thursday, which raised more than $1 million for AIDS Project Los Angeles.   Of the nearly 300 models who walked down the runway, 30 wore silver bathing or body suits. Eighteen women went down the catwalk in black stockings and lacy underwear. They were followed by a cavalcade of shirtless men with hardly a chest hair among them.

nytimes_articles.headline: Fire Islanders Try To Fill the Breach
nytimes_articles.abstract: Fire Islanders have undertaken the responsibility to do as much as possible to conserve and protect the Fire Island barrier island. Year after year we have invested hundreds of thousands of homeowner private dollars and thousands of person-hours to build and rebuild dunes. We have an enlightened self-interest to protect our own homes as well as the thousands of homes on the northern side of Great South Bay, which would suffer constant storm flooding should a new inlet be riven through Fire Island.

nytimes_articles.headline:
TRAVEL ADVISORY;
New Terminal Opens at O'Hare
nytimes_articles.abstract:
For eight years, international travelers arriving at O'Hare Airport have had to negotiate a cramped makeshift terminal on the lower level of a parking lot, board buses from the plane to customs and search for friends or family in a crowd packed behind barricades.

Not any more. A $618 million international terminal for arrivals opened at O'Hare last month.  It will open for departures in October; until then, departing passengers will continue to use the interim terminal.

nytimes_articles.headline: Alfresco Dining, Mediterranean Style
nytimes_articles.abstract: WHEN Ed Brown, who is the executive chef at Tropica, the Manhattan seafood restaurant, catered the wedding last year of Pierre Franey's son Jacques to Trish Cancalosi on the beach in East Hampton, he prepared a spectacular outdoor meal for 200 guests. But instead of making stews and casseroles to be reheated, everything was either cooked on the spot or served at room temperature. To do this, he brought along a convoy of chefs from Manhattan who had worked through the night to prepare the meal.    "I went for the Provencal style," he said. "I chose the sort of things you see on the Cote d'Azur, in Tuscany or Tunisia: roast vegetables, grains, herbs, olives, oil, garlic -- boldly, highly seasoned food." While an army of chefs may have been needed to put together the food for the wedding, the individual dishes are simple enough for the home cook to prepare with ease. They are great for a summer picnic or outdoor meal on a warm day.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Use of Psychics In Seeking the Missing
nytimes_articles.abstract: The recent article "Psychics on Trail of Missing Persons" is an interesting and disturbing display of tabloid-style reporting.

nytimes_articles.headline: Hikers Seek New Trails to Conquer
nytimes_articles.abstract: PEOPLE collect all kinds of things from Old Master paintings to barbed wire, from eggs to baseball cards. In climbing and hiking circles mountains are collected as assiduously as are first editions by bibliophiles. The sport is known as peak bagging.   There is nothing tangible to show for it, just the satisfaction of having reached the summit and possibly the opportunity to join an organization of climbers of similar achievement.

nytimes_articles.headline: Where There's Smoke There May Be Legislation
nytimes_articles.abstract: A small but committed band of state legislators in Hartford has waged war for years to try to ban smoking at the State Capitol and other public buildings. And every year, tobacco lobbyists and politicians who still recall Connecticut's days as a major tobacco-growing state shoot the bill down in flames.    But this week, even as the smoke in the Capitol corridors appeared to thicken, so did the plot. The bill, which died weeks ago in committee, was resurrected as an amendment on the floor of the House of Representatives and sent to the Senate, where it remains in line on a jammed calendar with only a few days remaining before session's adjournment at midnight on Wednesday.

nytimes_articles.headline: DENTAL COVERAGE URGED BY EXPERTS
nytimes_articles.abstract: As the nation ponders what to do for 37 million Americans who lack medical insurance, many health experts say it is also time to extend basic dental benefits to the 150 million Americans who lack such coverage.   That would be a break with tradition. The last time the country passed sweeping health programs, in the mid-1960's, dentistry was all but ignored. Medicare, the program for the elderly, provides no dental care while Medicaid, for the poor, offers only spotty and shrinking coverage.

nytimes_articles.headline: 'A Woman at War': Covering Boomer's War
nytimes_articles.abstract: ANYONE who ever wanted a front-row seat in a war theater will find it in Molly Moore's tense first-person chronology of Operations Desert Shield and Desert Storm. As the senior military correspondent for The Washington Post, already familiar with Pentagon officials, Ms. Moore had a house seat, afforded by Lieut. Gen. Walter Boomer, the commanding general of the Marine forces.

nytimes_articles.headline: Ideal Liberalism
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   John Gray has published splenetic dismissals of John Rawls's ideas with reliable frequency. It is therefore surprising that his review of Mr. Rawls's "Political Liberalism" (May 16) begins so respectfully, but not surprising that it ends so nastily. Mr. Gray says almost nothing about the content of the book and describes Mr. Rawls's position only in the broadest terms, before going on to complain that it "has nothing to say to our contemporaries in Ankara, in Delhi, in St. Petersburg or in Shanghai."

nytimes_articles.headline: Lisa R. Ianuzi, Charles Samkoff
nytimes_articles.abstract: Lisa Renee Ianuzi, the associate graphic director of men's design at the Polo/Ralph Lauren Corporation in New York, was married last evening to Charles Bruce Samkoff, an associate in corporate finance at Rothschild Inc., the investment banking company in New York. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel and the Rev. Johanna Johanson, an Episcopal minister, jointly performed the ceremony at the Stouffer Westchester Hotel in White Plains.   Mrs. Samkoff, 26, graduated from the University of Denver, as did her husband. She is a daughter of Mrs. Anthony Nicoletti and James B. Ianuzi, both of Syracuse.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Day Later, 2 More Tests
nytimes_articles.abstract: Act 2 coming up: The day after Belmont Day will crowd the racing stage with stars, too, notably the grass champion of last year, the colt Lure, and the prime filly Sky Beauty, both seeking 1993 championships.   Lure will face seven rivals in the $150,000 Manhattan Handicap, and will be after rewards beyond the purse: If he wins, he will sweep the Early Times Turf Series and win the $1 million bonus that goes with it.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
nytimes_articles.abstract: ONE HUNDRED HUNGRY ANTS By Elinor J. Pinczes. Illustrated by Bonnie MacKain. Unpaged. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $13.95. (Ages 5 to 9) FEAST FOR 10 Written and illustrated by Cathryn Falwell. Unpaged. New York: Clarion Books. $14.95. (Ages 3 to 7) THE TWELVE CIRCUS RINGS Written and illustrated by Seymour Chwast. Unpaged. San Diego: Gulliver Books/ Harcourt Brace & Company. $14.95. (Ages 4 to 8)

nytimes_articles.headline: Louise Whitton, Clifton G. York
nytimes_articles.abstract: Louise Whitton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Whitton Jr. of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married yesterday to Clifton Gaston York, the son of Janet Brewster of New York and the late Dr. Albert T. York Jr. The Rev. John M. Whallon performed the ceremony at the Rye (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church.   Mrs. York is an actress in New York. She graduated cum laude from Middlebury College. Mr. York is studying for an M.B.A. at New York University. He graduated from the University of Virginia.

nytimes_articles.headline: Stressing Local Food and Know-How
nytimes_articles.abstract: SAY goodbye to spatzle and brandy-cream sauces and hello to Peconic Bay mussels and tuna carpaccio. Berclaz, a traditional Swiss restaurant in Bridgehampton, is gone. In its place is 95 School Street. From a culinary and geographical perspective, the newcomer is half a world away from Switzerland and firmly anchored on the East End.   Ninety-Five School Street is the quintessential Hamptons spot, with light airiness, masses of fresh flowers, creamy walls and occasional whimsical art. Its pressed-tin ceiling, antique mahogany-and-copper bar and old-fashioned lighting fixtures provide texture. The tile floors add to the cool crisp look, but they also augment the high noise level on crowded evenings.

nytimes_articles.headline: Let Jordan Be
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Sports Editor:   I am alarmed that you allow Dave Anderson to publish such utter trash as "Jordan's Atlantic City Caper" (The Times, May 27). Anderson gets one thing right: Jordan is free to gamble in a legal casino. Anderson is dead wrong on everything else including his question on Jordan's timing.

nytimes_articles.headline: Valerie Gordon, Doug Johnson
nytimes_articles.abstract: Valerie Gordon, a theatrical producer, was married yesterday to Doug Johnson, a partner in Dodger Productions, a theatrical producer, both in New York. The Rev. Thomas D. Bowers performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York.   Mrs. Gordon-Johnson, an associate producer of the Broadway musical "Crazy for You," graduated from Sweet Briar College and the Art Center College of Design. She is the daughter of Crawford and Catherine A. Gordon of Kaycee, Wyo.

nytimes_articles.headline: Democratic Deja Vu
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   The film "Dave"  [ "Of Hems and Haws: The Insiders' Guide to 'Dave,' " May 16 ]  parallels another film that opened at the dawn of another Democrat's Presidency. "Gabriel Over the White House" (1933), directed by Gregory La Cava, tells a similar story of a country under an out-of-touch President facing seemingly insurmountable problems.

nytimes_articles.headline: Kamsky at Dortmund: Right in the Middle
nytimes_articles.abstract: GATA KAMSKY ended up right in the middle of the field of the Dortmund (Germany) International Tournament, held over the Easter holidays. The 19-year-old from Brooklyn scored 3 1/2-3 1/2 to tie for fourth place with Sergei Dolmatov of Russia in the eight-grandmaster round-robin event, which was won by Anatoly Karpov, the former world champion.    Still, Kamsky did brighten up an otherwise undistinguished result by executing a nice mating attack against 20-year-old Joel Lautier of France in Round 3.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Coming Clash of Civilizations Or, the West Against the Rest
nytimes_articles.abstract:
World politics is entering a new phase in which the fundamental source of conflict will be neither ideological or economic. The great divisions among mankind and the dominating source of conflict will be cultural. The principal conflicts of global politics will occur between nations and groups of different civilizations. The clash of civilizations will dominate global politics. 

During the cold war, the world was divided into the first, second and third worlds. Those divisions are no longer relevant. It is far more meaningful to group countries not in terms of their political or economic systems or their level of economic development but in terms of their culture and civilization.

nytimes_articles.headline: Gardeners Hope to Keep a Piece of Southern Black Culture Alive
nytimes_articles.abstract: More then 100 people gathered in a sunny field here today to pay homage to a spikey, hay-like plant -- sweetgrass -- that has long been essential to the black culture along the coast but is now endangered by development.   The volunteers, trowels in hand, planted more than 2,000 small clumps of sweetgrass on a one-acre inland plot on James Island, far from the sandy dunes where the grass once thrived. The effort is part of an experiment to determine whether the plant can flourish under cultivation, and again supply the basket-making craft that has been part of black culture here for 300 years.

nytimes_articles.headline: Tara A. Scully, M. S. Rockefeller
nytimes_articles.abstract: Tara Anne Scully, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis P. Scully Jr. of Marblehead, Mass., was married there yesterday to Michael Sorum Rockefeller, a son of Rodman C. Rockefeller of New York and the late Barbara O. Rockefeller. The Rev. Dennis Burns performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at Our Lady, Star of the Sea Church.   Mrs. Rockefeller was until recently a senior merchandise manager with the Manhattan Menswear Group of the Salant Corporation, a clothing manufacturer in New York. She graduated cum laude from Middlebury College. Her father is the president of Scully International, a real-estate marketing company in Marblehead.

nytimes_articles.headline: No Bail for 2 Charged in Teacher's Slaying
nytimes_articles.abstract: Two Brooklyn teen-agers charged in the fatal shooting of a drama teacher in Prospect Park last week were ordered held without bail at an arraignment yesterday in Brooklyn Criminal Court.   Judge Albert D. Koch set bail at $300,000 for two other Brooklyn youths who have been charged in the slaying of the teacher, Allyn Winslow. Mr. Winslow, 42, was shot four times on Tuesday when he fought off efforts to steal his mountain bike, the police said.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Rustic Place To Hang a Hat
nytimes_articles.abstract: You can search for original furniture till the cows come home. Here it is in the form of what its maker, Stephen Spooner, calls a gentleman's cupboard. The piece has the chipped-paint door of a rural outhouse, dimensions like those of a phone booth and a peaked shingle roof suggestive of a fractured fairy tale.

nytimes_articles.headline: In Decade of Study, Few Gains on AIDS
nytimes_articles.abstract: With more than 14 million people worldwide infected with the virus that causes AIDS and the disease spreading at an alarming rate, scientists are heading into the ninth international meeting on AIDS this weekend in Berlin seeking a breakthrough. But after a decade of research that has yielded neither a cure nor a vaccine, it appears that they will leave with few answers for the many questions about the virus that causes AIDS and the course of the disease.    Article, page 20.

nytimes_articles.headline:
Connecticut Q&A;: Alexandra Stoddard;
Daffodils Should Be 'Not Just for Visitors'
nytimes_articles.abstract:
IT sounds so simple: "Creating a Beautiful Home." But the subject and title of the most recent book by the interior designer and writer Alexandra Stoddard can be more than a little intimidating to those who think they lack the flair -- or the funds -- for home decorating. 

That need not be the case, insists Ms. Stoddard, arguing that the tools of interior design are at everyone's fingertips. A sort of self-help home decorating guide, her latest book (published by William Morrow last year) chronicles the renovation of Ms. Stoddard's own 18th-century cottage in Stonington. The book provides what she describes as a "very 90's" look at the world of interior design, where affordable taste reigns. Hers is a world full not only of chintz, antiques and collectibles but also of rag rugs and do-it-yourself paint jobs.

nytimes_articles.headline: Where Thin-Crusted Pizza Is a Highlight
nytimes_articles.abstract: AT first sight, Al Forno Brick Oven Pizzeria and Ristorante in Old Saybrook looks like a typical pizzeria, with the cooks at work in the rear, pulling and tossing dough and extracting finished pies from the oven with long-handled peels. A waiting line for seats and take-out orders forms at the right side of the room next to a long counter. Alongside the closely spaced tables are auxiliary tables with huge trays of hot pizzas.   Even before opening the menu, one is aware of several touches that differentiate Al Forno from the usual no-frills pizzeria: the golden terra cotta tiles on the floor, the malachite green table tops, and the seven panels along one wall painted to resemble windows opening to a tranquil countryside that evokes Italy. On each table is a dish of succulent black and green olives and chunks of focaccia.

nytimes_articles.headline: Brotherly Love Goes Down for the Count
nytimes_articles.abstract: KUSUO EGUCHI stopped his younger brother KATSUAKI in the sixth round of the scheduled 10-round bout yesterday to win the Japan strawweight title in Japan's first brother-brother title bout. The referee stopped the bout at 2 minutes 12 seconds of the sixth round when Kusuo punished Katsuaki with right and left combinations and a left uppercut. Kusuo knocked down Katsuaki in the first round and was floored by his younger brother in the second round. Both entered pro boxing in 1989. Kusuo was Japan's top-ranked strawweight, and Katsuaki was ranked No. 3. Kusuo, 24, and Katsuaki, 22, come from a family of 10 brothers and 4 sisters. (AP)

nytimes_articles.headline: Louisiana State Women Take 7th Straight Title
nytimes_articles.abstract: Clare Eichner of Wisconsin completed a rare sweep of the middle-distance races at the National Collegiate Athletic Association championships, both indoors and out, when she won the 1,500 meters tonight. But even that wasn't enough to keep Louisiana State from winning its seventh consecutive women's team title.   L.S.U. scored 93 points to more than double Wisconsin's second-place score of 44 points.

nytimes_articles.headline: Land of the Raj
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor: Many happy memories were brought back by Julie Sahni's article about India. Most people are unaware of this "hill station" resort in southern India. Darjeeling and Simla are two names that people are much more familiar with; however, these are in the northern part of the country.   I was sorry that Ms. Sahni did not include Coonoor, a nearby town, the other major community in the Nilgiri Hills. Coonoor compares very favorably with Ootacamund as a resort area and should not be overlooked..

nytimes_articles.headline: Adventures in Russia'a Far East
nytimes_articles.abstract: The loosening of travel restrictions to the Russian Far East has spawned a number of new adventure tours to places formerly closed to foreigners. The destinations include the Kamchatka Peninsula, the strategic military area over which Korean Airlines Flight 007 flew before it was shot down by the Russians in 1983.    "Crossroads of Continents -- Remote Alaska and the Russian Far East Above the Arctic Circle," is an 11-day voyage aboard Clipper Adventure Cruises' 138-passenger World Discoverer, a ship built especially for navigation through ice-strewn waters. The ship, which will follow 18th- and 19th-century exploration routes, departs Nome July 11, 21 and 31 and Aug. 10. Stops in Russia include the whaling village of Novoye Chaplino, the town of Provideniya and Uelen, an isolated Chukchi village, the easternmost outpost of the Russian continent. Guides will be on hand to identify wildlife, such as Pacific walruses, whales and polar bears, and to lecture on Russian, Aleut, Chukchi and Yuit culture and history. Cost per person, double occupancy, is $3,500 to $5,200 and does not include air fare. Information: Clipper Adventure Cruises, 7711 Bonhomme Avenue, St. Louis, Mo. 63105; (800) 325-0010.

nytimes_articles.headline: NEW PLANS READY FOR SPACE STATION
nytimes_articles.abstract: The nine-year, $9 billion space-station program enters a crucial phase this week as the Clinton Administration ends a four-month bid to slim down the proposed outpost for orbiting astronauts while weighing full participation by the Russians.   The process of redesign, as full of zigs and zags as the beleaguered station program itself, has produced three alternatives, each progressively cheaper than the $31 billion, 350-foot design that the Clinton White House inherited from the Bush Administration.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Focus Is on Delmore Schwartz
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   I appreciate the favorable review by Michael Milburn of my edition of "Delmore Schwartz and James Laughlin: Selected Letters" (May 9). Mr. Milburn expressed some concern about the "imbalance" of the number of letters by Schwartz versus those by Laughlin.

nytimes_articles.headline: NEW CLUES FOUND IN FATAL ILLNESSES
nytimes_articles.abstract: Researchers sounded notably if guardedly optimistic today that they had indeed found the cause of a mysterious flu-like illness responsible for killing 11 and gravely sickening 7 others in New Mexico and Arizona.   When scientists announced Friday night that they believed the disease was caused by a rodent virus called hanta virus, they were hesitant and quick to caveat every word. Today, the caveats had been cut roughly in half. "It has not been conclusively confirmed, and there's a lot we do not know," Dr. Fred Koster of the University of New Mexico Medical Center said at a news conference here today. "But there's a very good possibility we're seeing the agent that could cause this type of syndrome."

nytimes_articles.headline: Mary LaTulip, John L. Troost
nytimes_articles.abstract: Mary Lauren LaTulip, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kevin LaTulip of West Chester, Pa., was married yesterday to John Laurens Troost, the son of Joan Troost of Seekonk, Mass., and the late John Troost. The Rev. Thomas E. Moye, an American Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.   Ms. LaTulip, who is keeping her name, is a systems manager for Advantage Inc., a temporary-employment agency in New York. She graduated from Columbia University, as did her husband. Her father is the branch manager, in Columbia, Md., of the Reliance Insurance Company. Her mother, Carolyn LaTulip, is an elementary-school teacher at East Ward School in Downingtown, Pa.

nytimes_articles.headline: Tracy Callaghan, John Torrente Jr.
nytimes_articles.abstract: Tracy Lynn Callaghan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Callaghan of Ridgewood, N.J., was married yesterday to John Joseph Torrente Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Torrente Sr. of Ridgewood. The Rev. Arvin Ten Brink performed the Dutch Reformed ceremony at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.   Mrs. Torrente, 25, is an administrative assistant in the institutional credit department at Bear, Stearns & Company, the securities brokerage. Her father is the president of SPG Group, the securities clearing division of Shearson Lehman Brothers in New York.

nytimes_articles.headline: Top Graduates in Science Also Put Dreams on Hold
nytimes_articles.abstract: These are unsettling job-hunting times, even for the certifiably brilliant progeny of the nation's top schools in science and engineering.    Seniors who had their hearts set on creating the technologies of the next century are having trouble just lining up job interviews, and fresh new Ph.D.'s are settling for temporary teaching jobs offering little prospect of the security of tenure.

nytimes_articles.headline:
FOCUS;
Tenfold Growth for a Tiny Bay Area City?
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Just two weeks after the City Council of this farming community 40 miles east of San Francisco gave its approval to the largest residential development in local history -- a 1,031-house subdivision by A.G. Spanos Construction Company of Stockton -- it approved the second-largest. It will have 940 houses. Hancock Construction Company of Saratoga is the builder. 

Still to come is a proposal by the Cowell Foundation, a San Francisco charitable organization, to develop the 4,900-acre Cowell Ranch adjacent to this city into a 7,500-home community complete with schools, parks and retail and employment centers.

nytimes_articles.headline: Back in the Swim With Fresh Air Fund
nytimes_articles.abstract: While staying with a Massachusetts family last summer, Keenen Jackson, 11, of Staten Island, learned how to fish but not how to tell a fish story.   "I've caught fish in the pond," he announced proudly at a pizza party recently for Fresh Air Fund children from Staten Island. But, holding his index fingers a few inches apart, he admitted, "They were really little fish."

nytimes_articles.headline: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
nytimes_articles.abstract: HORSEMAN OF THE YEAR   County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke will acquire the title "Horseman of the Year" today, to be bestowed on him during ceremonies at 10 A.M. at the North Ridge Equestrian Center, 960 California Road in Eastchester.

nytimes_articles.headline: 1 Standard for All
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Sports Editor:   If The Times's reports about Michael Jordan's gambling activities are correct, then the National Basketball Association should suspend Jordan for one year. Bulls forward Horace Grant is right: We should not have one standard for Michael Jordan and a wholly different standard for everybody else. A double standard communicates the message that, as long as you are a great player, you can do anything you want and get away with it. By suspending Michael Jordan for gambling activities, the N.B.A. will safeguard the integrity and credibility of professional basketball and also send an important and much needed message about character. HAVEN BRADFORD GOW Arlington Heights, Ill.

nytimes_articles.headline: Faye Fisher, Alan Zwiebel
nytimes_articles.abstract: Rabbi and Mrs. David Fisher have announced the engagement of their daughter Faye Fisher to Alan H. Zwiebel, a son of Mrs. Harry Garber of Lawrence, L.I., and the late Louis J. Zwiebel. A spring 1994 wedding is planned.   Ms. Fisher is a restaurant advertising consultant in New York with Transmedia Network Inc., a financial services company for restaurants. She and her fiance graduated from Brooklyn College, from which she also received a master's degree in drama.

nytimes_articles.headline:
The View From: Scarsdale;
Sunday Morning at the Movies (for Non-Sun Worshipers)
nytimes_articles.abstract:
WOULD anyone go to the movies at 10 o'clock on a summer Sunday morning? Marilyn Ackerman and Beth Kochen, who run the Westchester Cinema Club, are betting that the answer is yes.

For 13 years in the fall, winter and spring, the club has shown films that Mrs. Ackerman describes as artistic, intellectual, geared for select audiences on Sunday mornings at the 350-seat Fine Arts Cinema here. Now, for the first time, the club is starting a summer series. The opening offering, on June 27, is "A Brief History of Time," a documentary about Stephen Hawking, a noted British physicist who has amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or Lou Gehrig's disease.

nytimes_articles.headline: NEWS SUMMARY
nytimes_articles.abstract: International 3-21  U.N. TROOPS CLASH WITH SOMALIS

nytimes_articles.headline: North and South Join Classic Tale's Study
nytimes_articles.abstract:
SUSAN ROSS, an English teacher at Yorktown High School, became dissatisfied last year with the way she had been teaching "To Kill a Mockingbird," the classic novel of a white girl growing up in the segregated South. 

The 1960 work by Harper Lee about a small-town lawyer's defense in the 1930's of a black man falsely accused of raping a white woman is told from his daughter's perspective. The story was based on her father's career.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sallie Saunders And John Colucci
nytimes_articles.abstract: Sallie Alyce Saunders, a manager in the human resources department at Time Inc. in New York, was married yesterday to John Anthony Colucci, a vice president of new business development in Pelham, N.Y., for Gulfstream Aerospace, a corporate jet manufacturer based in Savannah, Ga. The Rev. Jack Roche performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church in Pelham Manor, N.Y.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Lawyer Vanishes
nytimes_articles.abstract:
PLEADING GUILTY
By Scott Turow.
386 pp. New York:
Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $24.

nytimes_articles.headline: Menopause: New Research And Treatment
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THE Red Hot Mamas of Marin County, Calif., and the Crones of Crossville, Tenn., have nothing on a number of people on Long Island who are making the once-taboo subject of menopause a topic of intense discussion and changes in life styles. 

Once associated with decline, and even death, menopause is the stage of a woman's life -- in America about the age of 51 -- when her reproductive powers end. For many it is fraught with anguish over physical and psychological symptoms, anxiety about a decline in sexuality and confusion about the "appropriate" role of the older woman.

nytimes_articles.headline: Miss Graebner, Mr. Hertz
nytimes_articles.abstract: Cameron Clark Graebner, the daughter of Carole Caldwell Graebner of New York and Clark E. Graebner of Southport, Conn., was married yesterday to Brian Seth Hertz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Hertz of Merrick, L.I. Chief Judge Thomas Poole Griesa of Federal District Court in Manhattan, officiated at the Harvard Club in New York.   Mrs. Hertz, 26, was until recently the personal assistant in New York to the president of Martha Inc., the fashion-boutique company. Her father is the senior vice president of sales for the Corporate Printing Company in New York. Her mother is the vice president and national advertising director for Tennis Week magazine, also in New York. The bride's parents are former professional tennis players.

nytimes_articles.headline: Large Step for Knicks But It's Small Solace
nytimes_articles.abstract: For so many reasons, it was painful for the Knicks to wake up yesterday and accept that their season was over. Painful because after a 60-victory regular season, the Knicks and many others believed they were good enough to win a National Basketball Association championship. Painful because mistakes like missed free throws and turnovers cost them dearly.   Painful because veterans like Patrick Ewing, Charles Oakley, Doc Rivers, Rolando Blackman and Herb Williams must endure another year without a title.

nytimes_articles.headline: Miss Eberstadt, Mr. Bruton
nytimes_articles.abstract: Fernanda Eberstadt, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Eberstadt of New York, was married yesterday to Alastair Meddon Oswald Bruton, a son of Mrs. D. C. Bruton of Hockworthy, Devon, England, and the late Mr. Bruton. The Rev. W. Clarke Prescott performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. Paul's Chapel in New York.   Mrs. Bruton graduated from Magdalen College, Oxford University. She is an author whose novels, "Low Tide" and "Isaac and His Devils," were published by Knopf.

nytimes_articles.headline: Furniture With Grit, a la Hamptons
nytimes_articles.abstract: WITH Bottleworks Marketplace, a new store in Sag Harbor, L.I., that sells furniture made of antique barn wood, the carpenters Stephen and William Spooner may have hit the marketing nail right on the head. The two brothers, who specialize in relocating 18th- and 19th-century post-and-beam barns and houses on Long Island and in Connecticut, recycle leftover barn wood into unpretentiously rustic furnishings, including cupboards, tables, armoires and chests.   There is also an unerring eye at work in the selection of accessories and other antiques, like birdhouses ($40 to $65), wrought-iron candlesticks ($20 to 40 each) and wicker furniture ($1,200 for a graceful sofa and two matching chairs).

nytimes_articles.headline: Dr. Zawaiza, Mr. Tanzersan
nytimes_articles.abstract: Dr. Theda Ruth Wiles Zawaiza, a senior legislative analyst in Washington for Representative Major R. Owens, Democrat of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Bradford Tanzersan, a legal assistant in Washington. The Rev. Robert O. Simpson performed the ceremony at Janes United Methodist Church in Brooklyn.   Dr. Zawaiza graduated from Colgate University and received a master's degree in education from the University of Southern California. She received a Ph.D. in education from the University of California at Santa Barbara. She is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund T. Wiles of Brooklyn. The bride's previous marriage ended in divorce.

nytimes_articles.headline: POSTINGS: Regional Planning Conference; Workshops on Making the Area Work
nytimes_articles.abstract: Anyone who believes that "united we stand" is as applicable to states as to people might enjoy the Regional Plan Association's day-long conference this Tuesday. The association, which is dedicated to getting New York, New Jersey and Connecticut to set joint policies that can improve the quality of life in all three states, says that by day's end a blueprint will have emerged for turning this area into "The Region That Works."   The meeting will offer a series of workshops dealing with such subjects as rebuilding and expanding the region's infrastructure, protecting its environmental resources, training its labor, and ways of wooing companies -- and jobs -- to the area.

nytimes_articles.headline: State's Schools Mandate Joins Parents and Staffs
nytimes_articles.abstract: WHEN the chairman of the science department at Herricks High School, Leonard Giordano, explained his proposal to change the curriculum to the 30 teachers, parents, administrators and students gathered at the Herricks Community Center, they listened attentively to his reasoning.   "Science teachers can't possibly cover every optional subject in the curriculum," Mr. Giordano said. "If they do, they're doing their students a disservice. The proposal to allow teachers to select optional units for in-depth study while still preparing students for the Regents exam gives them greater flexibility and gives their students a well-rounded understanding of the core areas and methods of scientific investigation."

nytimes_articles.headline: Ms. Friedman, Mr. Kushner
nytimes_articles.abstract: Stephanie Paige Friedman, the daughter of Dr. Melvin M. Friedman and Joyce Ezrine, both of Baltimore, was married there yesterday to Thomas Nicholas Kushner, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Kushner. The Rev. John S. Witulich, a Roman Catholic priest, and Cantor Harold Levy officiated at the Woodholme Country Club.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Fugitive's Tale Sheds Light On China Today
nytimes_articles.abstract: One of the astonishing facts of the Tiananmen Square protest in Beijing four years ago was that 8 of the 21 students on the security police's most-wanted list managed to evade arrest and eventually to escape to the West. It happens, moreover, that China, at least until recently, has had a security apparatus so ruthlessly efficient that escape was hardly thought of, much less attempted. And so, the question is: How did the students do it?    At least a partial answer is provided by "Escape From China," a 57-minute documentary by Iris F. Kung, the pseudonym of a Chinese television reporter now living in the United States. The film, which will be shown Friday and Saturday at the Anthology Film Archives, tells the story of 25-year-old Zhang Boli, one of the most prominent of the student leaders and the person who hid in China longer than any other of the hunted dissidents.

nytimes_articles.headline:
The Deadly Sins/Sloth;
Nearer, My Couch, to Thee
nytimes_articles.abstract:
When the sun blazes down on the hot sidewalk by day, and the sidewalk radiates it back by night, perhaps your thoughts, panicky with heat, plunge toward the idea of never-ending swelter, of eternal damnation to a windless city. At such a time, you might even start considering the traditional path to such damnation, the deadly sins -- sloth, anger, lust, envy, gluttony, pride and avarice. How often we have been told that our godless age has lost its sense of sin! 

But is that really so? Have the rules changed? Have the sins changed? 

Or is sin an idea whose time has finally passed?

nytimes_articles.headline: NOTES
nytimes_articles.abstract: The latest George Michael video has a piercing quality -- as in pierced lips and pierced noses. Bellybuttons and eyebrows, too. "We shot all these hip-hop rave kids at subway stations," said Marcus Nispel, 30, the video's German director. "They are the guys who come up with style. They go to Woolworth's and the Salvation Army, and they make something out of it." Mr. Nispel has interspersed these urban scenes with cartoon images that spoof popular products like Tide and Mr. Clean. "It's about how the marketing of these fashion trends went really, really fast," he said. "How a trend comes out, and three months later it's a whole floor at Bloomingdale's."

nytimes_articles.headline: Off-Duty Officer Shot
nytimes_articles.abstract: An off-duty police officer was shot in Staten Island yesterday as an assailant robbed him outside a bank, the police said. The officer, Detective Dominick Trancucci, 42, was approaching the Gateway State Bank on Forest Avenue about 5:30 P.M. to deposit about $2,000 into the bank's drop slot when he was accosted by a man carrying a handgun, said Sgt. John McCluskey, a police spokesman. Detective Trancucci struggled for the gun, said Sergeant McCluskey, and was shot in his left shoulder. Detective Trancucci, a 19-year veteran of the police force, was taken to St. Vincent's Hospital in Staten Island, where he was listed in stable condition last night, said Sergeant McCluskey. His assailant fled with the cash.

nytimes_articles.headline: MORE PEOPLE VIEW CLINTON AS LIBERAL AS HE SEEKS CENTER
nytimes_articles.abstract: As President Clinton struggles to return to the centrist policies that won the election, an increased number of Americans view him as a liberal, and many say his economic plan relies too heavily on raising taxes and would do little to help the economy, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.   Most Americans do not appear convinced by Mr. Clinton's repeated efforts to show that his economic remedies will place a heavier burden on rich people than on the middle class. And they have grown increasingly skeptical about the fairness and effectiveness of the plan.

nytimes_articles.headline: French Foursome Has Bermuda Bowl Hopes
nytimes_articles.abstract: BASED on past performance, there is a strong possibility that the final of the 1993 World Championship, which will be contested for the Bermuda Bowl in Santiago, Chile, in September, will be between the United States and France. That would repeat the 1992 final in Salsomaggiore, Italy, when the French were victorious.   The Americans and the French have met on 19 official or semi-official occasions. There have been six French victories, four of them en route to world titles, and 12 American victories. A 1932 match was abandoned as a draw after a dispute.

nytimes_articles.headline: Public & Private; Political Illiteracy
nytimes_articles.abstract: There's a certain kind of conversation you have from time to time at parties in New York about a new book. The word "banal" sometimes rears its by-now banal head; you say "underedited," I say "derivative." The conversation goes around and around various literary criticisms, and by the time it moves on one thing is clear: no one read the book, we just read the reviews.    A variation on those conversations has taken place in Washington over the last month about the past opinions of an accomplished and ill-treated woman named Lani Guinier.

nytimes_articles.headline: Weapons Measure Hits a Roadblock in Hartford
nytimes_articles.abstract: A bill to ban the sale of semiautomatic military-style assault rifles in Connecticut tumbled into parliamentary limbo late Friday night in the state Senate, clouding the proposal's chances with time running out before the General Assembly's adjournment on Wednesday.   Sportsmen's groups and lobbyists for the National Rifle Association, which has launched a major effort to kill the bill, were jubilant but still remained cautious today. The bill's proponents were confused by the turn of events.

nytimes_articles.headline: The View From: Hampton; How a Small Town Reveals Americans' Values
nytimes_articles.abstract: OCCASIONALLY Janet and James Robertson asked about the history of their village. One day, Mrs. Robertson recalled, "the past came to our door. Wendell Davis just came, with a great big box full of stuff." Added her husband: "It had clearly not been packed, just dumped. We pulled out a Yale catalogue from 1820." The couple would pull much more from the past.    The Robertsons live in Hampton, where two rows of sturdy houses line a little stretch of road through the hills of northeastern Connecticut. In 1967 they bought an 18th-century house there from Mr. Davis and his brothers, whose family had bought it in 1804.  They got to know Mr. Davis, but they didn't know that for 150 years his ancestors -- Taintors and Davises -- had saved just about everything, including college catalogues, personal letters, business records, newspapers, pamphlets, pictures and an 1853 key to "Uncle Tom's Cabin." The family removed all of it before selling the house.

nytimes_articles.headline: Perspectives: Renewing the Branches; Carnegie's Library Parade Marches On
nytimes_articles.abstract: A GRATIFYING sight awaits Andrew Carnegie should he decide to materialize on Amboy Road in the Tottenville section of Staten Island. A library built with his money in 1904 has been overhauled at a cost of $1.9 million by the Department of General Services. It reopened in March -- repaired, restored and braced for the brave new audio-visual world of the 90's.   The branch is one of at least 65 libraries built in New York City with the 19th-century industrialist's money, a fraction of more than 2,000 he paid for around the world. In New York, 52 of these buildings survive as libraries. None so far has received so extensive a restorative treatment as the one operating in an old-Americana setting at 7430 Amboy Road, at the southernmost tip of Staten Island.

nytimes_articles.headline: Eileen Weiler, Robert Judell
nytimes_articles.abstract: Eileen Weiler, a reading specialist at the Chapin School, was married on Wednesday to Robert Buchman Judell, the president and chief executive of James Thompson & Company, textile manufacturers. Both work in New York. Rabbi David M. Posner performed the ceremony at Temple Emanu-El in New York.

nytimes_articles.headline: Courier vs. Bruguera: Baseline Battery
nytimes_articles.abstract: Who's afraid of Jim Courier, the flint-eyed, two-time defending champion of the French Open who is back on the doorstep of a record third straight title?   Let's start off with Sergi Bruguera, Courier's Grand Slam neophyte challenger in a finale that promises to be chock-full of the baseline battery that has gotten them both where they are.

nytimes_articles.headline: Wine From Young Vines in Southern Ontario
nytimes_articles.abstract: NOT far from Niagara Falls in southern Ontario, venturesome wine-minded travelers will discover a region rich with young wineries. Like the Napa Valley of the early 1970's, the peninsula between Lake Ontario and Lake Erie is fertile territory for new, ambitious estates with big ideas. They are coaxing good wine from young grapevines and impatiently awaiting the nuances that come with older vines and more cellar experience.    Some 25 wineries -- 21 of them established since 1979 -- are cultivating grapes on 15,000 acres luxuriant with European vinifera vines. Entrepreneurs are so optimistic that applications for licenses to start 12 more wineries are pending before the provincial Liquor Control Board. Land values and planted acreage have risen. New buildings, German wine presses and sleek Italian bottling machines are appearing. And rising reputations are nudging revenues upward: Since 1990, sales of the peninsula's premium wines have increased 100 percent.
