nytimes_articles.headline: Susan B. Titman, Peter S. Hedges
nytimes_articles.abstract: Susan Bruce Titman, a daughter of John and Narcissa Titman of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Peter Simpson Hedges, a son of the Rev. Robert B. Hedges of San Angelo, Tex., and Carole Hedges of New York. The bridegroom's father, a retired Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at St. James Church in Woodstock, Vt.   The bride, an actress with the Circle Repertory Company in New York, performs as Susan Bruce. She graduated from the University of Michigan and received a master's degree in fine arts from New York University. Her father is a vice president in New York at Home Box Office, the cable television network. Her mother, now retired, lectured in New York on the theater. The bride's maternal grandfather, the late Rev. Dr. V. Carney Hargroves, was president of the Baptist World Alliance.

nytimes_articles.headline: Rifka Milder, Robert Sherman

Rabbi Shira Milgrom performed the ceremony at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.   Mrs. Sherman, 30, is a painter and the president of the Rifka Tie Company, a necktie designer in New York. She graduated from the California Institute of the Arts. Her father, a painter, retired as a professor of art at the City University of New York. Her mother is a painter and an art teacher at Junior High School 104 in Manhattan.

nytimes_articles.headline: Kindergarten's 111th Story Ends Happily
nytimes_articles.abstract: Arms waving and feet kicking, the costumed kindergartners at Public School 95 danced merrily onto a small wooden stage and crooned "Razzle Dazzle" and "Ease On Down the Road" -- songs that echoed eerily last week through their Brooklyn elementary school auditorium and the memories of onlookers.    Three months ago the children began rehearsing those songs as they stood shivering on the observation deck of the World Trade Center, awaiting rescue after a bomb exploded 110 floors below.

nytimes_articles.headline: Germany's Young Turks Say 'Enough' to the Bias
nytimes_articles.abstract: A 22-year-old Berlin woman who is pursuing a degree in business administration reflects one of Germany's greatest resources and, at the same time, one of its most troubling challenges.   She is bright, articulate and opinionated, and looks forward to a productive career that will be both lucrative and socially responsible. But although she was born and raised in Berlin and has never left her homeland except for vacations, she remains an outsider, viewed suspiciously by many Germans and with outright hostility by some.

nytimes_articles.headline: Night Bloomers and Venus Flytraps
nytimes_articles.abstract: ALL the garden books I am reading this year are colored by Sara Stein's "Noah's Garden: Restoring the Ecology of Our Own Back Yards," which tells the story of how one gardener began to realize that her neat and tidy lawn, her perennial beds full of exotic shrubs and flowers had left no place for wildlife. "Noah's Garden" has affected the way I read other books and also the way I look at plants. Now, when I am enraptured by a viburnum or a butterfly bush at the local nursery, I ask, is this one the birds and butterflies could use?   Anyone prone to falling asleep in botany class might enjoy NATURAL AFFAIRS: A Botanist Looks at the Attachments Between Plants and People (225 pp., Villard, $25), by Peter Bernhardt, whose first book was the whimsical "Wily Violets and Underground Orchids." Many botanists are adventurers (after all, they get paid to tramp through savannas and jungles) but few have the storyteller's ability to take the rest of us, for example, on a journey into the sexual parts of a flower -- to find the threads of a saffron crocus (Crocus sativus, if you care), uh, fascinating.

nytimes_articles.headline: Andrea Solomon, Calvin L. Parker
nytimes_articles.abstract: Andrea Remi Solomon, the daughter of Drs. Theo X. Solomon and Ines A. D. Solomon of Teaneck, N.J., was married on Friday to Calvin Lane Parker, a son of Dr. M. Jack Parker and Elaine H. Parker of Aurora, Ill. Wilbur Levin, the clerk for Kings County, officiated at the Botanical Gardens of the Snug Harbor Cultural Center in Livingston, S.I.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sign of Despair Evident At Dinner for Homeless
nytimes_articles.abstract: DESPITE the elegant setting and convivial atmosphere, there was a bittersweet quality to the May 27 Hope for the Homeless Dinner at the Rye Town Hilton. For the 900 guests attired in cocktail dresses and business suits the pleasure in greeting friends and socializing with like-minded colleagues was offset by disappointment that the annual event was in its eighth year.   Unlike other fund-raising functions, where guests would expect to see floral or balloon centerpieces, there were instead decorated bricks, a visible reminder of the need for affordable housing in the county. Westchester has the highest rate of homelessness in the state. And in a poignant paradox, the success of the dinner -- which was dedicated to the county's homeless children and raised about $40,000 for programs that serve them countywide -- only underscored the failure of county and local governments to solve the problem.

nytimes_articles.headline: China to Korea by Ferry
nytimes_articles.abstract:
"YOU can't get there from here."

"There" is the Republic of South Korea.  "Here" is the People's Republic of China.

nytimes_articles.headline: 'Pippen Flamboyant' Sends Bulls Into Finals
nytimes_articles.abstract: Perhaps now the word soft, that four-letter word in Scottie Pippen's business, will be set aside forever.    A year removed from his ankle miseries and Xavier McDaniel's wild-eyed pursuit that limited Pippen in the playoff series against the Knicks and raised persistent doubts about his game, he has lifted the Bulls to the championship series in a way that only an elite player can.

nytimes_articles.headline: Beware Neatness; It Can Be Terminal
nytimes_articles.abstract: When Sara and Marty Stein built their house here 12 years ago, they carved out a spot in the midst of red cedars, cat brier, multiflora roses, poison ivy and bittersweet. They kind of liked it that way.   "We thought our garden would end right here at the edge of the patio," said Ms. Stein, the author of the recently published "Noah's Garden" (Houghton Mifflin, $21.95). "We thought we'd just get somebody to mow."

nytimes_articles.headline: They Had Wings of Angels
nytimes_articles.abstract: Lynn Johnson and Michael O'Leary's EN ROUTE: Label Art From the Golden Age of Air Travel (120 pp., Chronicle, paper, $14.95) is a charmer, made up of very little (but always useful) text and page after page of exact color replicas of the labels produced by the airlines in the early decades to adorn one's luggage and service one's ego. Curiously, though flying was then more primitive, it was also more comfortable. In 1934, American Airlines coaxed Douglas Aircraft into coming up with something that would be called a DC-3. This pleasure dome would carry 14 passengers, with one berth each, from New York to Los Angeles. Before then, the trip took 25 hours and required 15 stops. Now you stopped only three times, and were there in 17 hours and 30 minutes. The volume's endpapers invoke the view-from-the-air of the modernist T.W.A. The graphic shows us two routes from west to east. To fly to Europe meant landings at Newfoundland, Ireland and Paris or Newfoundland, the Azores and Lisbon. It is the curse of the jet that except when traveling to the Far East one is never in it long enough to eat, drink, be merry and sleep. The label art reminds us at once of the airlines' utilitarian beginnings ("Hoosier Airplane Lines. 1923 Charter. 1924 Air Taxi. Serving Fort Wayne, Muncie, Indianapolis, Vincennes and Terre Haute. 'Silver Wings,' Operator") and of the ends they would go to in trying to make you feel loved. "American Flagship Skysleeper" wasn't a bag tag -- that was the legend painted on the hull of the DC-3. When ux and I went off on our wedding trip in 1950, we rented the tail end of the Pan Am DC-4, a mini-suite. Price? $150. . . . The old tags, it transpires, are valuable, so have a look in your attic.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Mortgage Hurdle Blocks Some Co-ops Sales
nytimes_articles.abstract: FOR Dianne Landi, home is a bird, a one-bedroom bird with long, slender wings and a large, curved beak.    When she and her then-newlywed husband, Anthony Denza, bought it six years ago, the co-op in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn was the first leg of their flight plan for family and future. But now the couple have a 4-year-old daughter, and Ms. Landi is expecting twins in October. They would like to sell their apartment and move to larger quarters; in fact they have been trying to sell it for two years. But they cannot.

nytimes_articles.headline: BOLIVIA TO VOTE FOR ITS PRESIDENT
nytimes_articles.abstract: Bolivians vote for a new President on Sunday, no small feat for a country that has a history of more military coups and dictatorships than any other in Latin America.   If, as predicted, the election goes off without violence and significant fraud, it will usher in the fourth consecutive civilian government since 1982, a remarkable period of stability for this nation. From 1964 to 1982, it had 16 governments, 14 of them military.

nytimes_articles.headline: Alexandra Golby, Jonathan Zeitlin
nytimes_articles.abstract: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph W. Golby of Peapack, N.J., and New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alexandra Jacqueline Golby, to Jonathan Henry Zeitlin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Gerald Zeitlin of Waban, Mass. A June 1994 wedding is planned.   Ms. Golby, 25, is a third-year medical student at Stanford University. She and her fiance, 28, graduated cum laude from Yale University. Her father is president and chief executive of the International Center in New York Inc., which helps newly arrived foreigners adjust to life in New York. Her mother, Monique Golby, is an art dealer in New York.

nytimes_articles.headline:
Focus: Brentwood, Calif.;
Tenfold Growth for a Tiny Bay Area City?
nytimes_articles.abstract:
JUST two weeks after the City Council of this farming community 40 miles east of San Francisco gave its approval to the largest residential development in local history -- a 1,031-house subdivision by A.G. Spanos Construction Company of Stockton -- it approved the second-largest. It will have 940 houses. Hancock Construction Company of Saratoga is the builder. 

Still to come is a proposal by the Cowell Foundation, a San Francisco charitable organization, to develop the 4,900-acre Cowell Ranch adjacent to this city into a 7,500-home community complete with schools, parks and retail and employment centers.

nytimes_articles.headline: Dollar Gains In Finland
nytimes_articles.abstract: American visitors to Finland this year will find many prices dramatically lower than two years ago, thanks to a sharp drop in the value of the Finnish currency and a recession in that country.   According to a study conducted at the end of 1992 by Suomen Gallup Oy, a Finnish polling organization, which compared the prices for such staples as hotel rooms and a McDonald's Big Mac in 12 Western European capitals, Helsinki fell below the median on all types of lodging and most restaurant purchases, as well as train travel and airline tickets. Exceptions included taxi fares, car rental and food bought at a grocery.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: Because of an editing error, an article on May 23 about the British royal family referred incorrectly in some copies to the son of Queen Elizabeth, besides Prince Charles, who has had marital troubles. He is Prince Andrew, not Prince Edward.

nytimes_articles.headline:
OUTDOORS;
Tuning Up With the Bankside Orchestra of the Green Drake
nytimes_articles.abstract:
I checked my watch shortly after arriving at my chosen pool near Fish's Eddy on the East Branch of the Delaware river. It was 7:45 P.M., early enough for me to figure out what I'd forgotten before I was rigged up and standing in the water. One of the best features of fishing the green drake spinner fall, which will occur on local waters until the middle of this month, is that it's almost impossible to show up late for the event. As long as you arrive without your headlights on, you're early.

Half an hour later, I sat down on a log and poured a cup of coffee from my thermos. It was unseasonably cool for the first of June, and the bankside orchestra was in no mood to play this evening. I had heard that there had been great falls of spinners here over the last few evenings. I hoped there would be at least one more.

nytimes_articles.headline: Jeanne M. Arney, Douglas A. Muller
nytimes_articles.abstract: Jeanne Marie Arney, an assistant treasurer at the Bank of New York, was married yesterday to Douglas Andrew Muller, a vice president in the corporate finance division of the Chase Manhattan Bank, in Hasbrouck Heights, N.J. The Rev. Thomas Sheffield performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church in Morristown, N.J.   Mrs. Muller graduated from Skidmore College and received an M.B.A. from New York University. She is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Terry O. Arney of Waterford, Va. Her father is a technical director at the Science Applications International Corporation, a technicalconsulting company in McLean, Va.

nytimes_articles.headline:
Long Island Q&A;: Jerome Swartz;
Bar Codes and Other Technology Leaps
nytimes_articles.abstract:
JEROME SWARTZ, chairman of Symbol Technologies of Bohemia, has used his knowledge of lasers to create a success story of startling proportions.

Mr. Swartz was a co-founder of Symbol Technologies in 1973, just as bar codes were gaining universal acceptance. The company's hand-held scanners garner two-thirds of their market, with a global share of 40 percent.

nytimes_articles.headline: A 300th Anniversary for Philipsburg
nytimes_articles.abstract:
PHILIPSBURG MANOR in North Tarrytown will celebrate its 300th anniversary on June 19 and 20, and the program will feature some typical events, typical, that is, for the late 17th century and early 18th century.

On those days, children will play with hoops; adults will compete in a tug of war and the music of the hurdy-gurdy, a hand organ, will fill the air. The food will be reminiscent of the year 1693: cold lemon-cucumber soup, whole wheat bread baked with wheat ground at the Philipsburg mill, grilled sausage and orange cookies (commemorating William of Orange). Soft drinks dispensed from a Colonial-style tavern will also be available.

nytimes_articles.headline: Dinkins and Council Face Fiscal Maw's 300 Million Sharp Teeth
nytimes_articles.abstract: The sky was dark and menacing over Lower Manhattan yesterday, but it was no match for the gloom inside City Hall, where New York's political leaders worked behind closed doors to scale back the size of the municipal government by a hefty $300 million.   Cutting funds for valued services like day-care, summer school and homeless drop-in centers is never appealing to elected officials. But Mayor David N. Dinkins, Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone and the 50 other members of the Council no doubt feel particularly vulnerable doing it now, just months before they will ask voters to re-elect them.

nytimes_articles.headline: E. D. Nickerson, J. H. Seltzer
nytimes_articles.abstract: Elizabeth Dey Nickerson, the daughter of Mrs. William M. Riegel of Memphis, and William H. Nickerson 3d of Plymouth, Mass., was married yesterday to Dr. Jonathan Howard Seltzer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Seltzer of Philadelphia. Steven Boyan, a leader of the Ethical Culture Society, officiated in Mount Vernon Park in Baltimore.   Ms. Nickerson, who is 30, is keeping her name. She is a manager of health communications programs at the Center for Communications Programs at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore, which promotes family planning in developing countries through the news media. She graduated from Georgetown University and received a master's degree in international development from Tufts University.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sports of The Times; Knicks Must Endure A Short Cold Summer
nytimes_articles.abstract: When the buzzer ended the Knicks' quest Friday night in the disco din of Chicago Stadium, their short cold summer began.   It's time to pay more attention to the Yankees and the Mets, to think about the Giants and Jets training camps, to await the United States Open in both golf and tennis. But it won't be that easy to forget the long, hot basketball season. Not so much the 96-88 loss to the Bulls here Friday night, but the 97-94 loss at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night, when the Knicks missed 15 free throws, when Charles Smith couldn't get through the spiderweb of arms above him in the final seconds.

nytimes_articles.headline: 2 Families Shattered by Bronx Shooting
nytimes_articles.abstract: They were two vivacious, bright-eyed boys who attended the same school and were in the same grade, but now their worlds have been ripped apart -- one of them dead and the other in the hospital with a bullet in his spine.   The two 7-year-old boys were victims caught in a fusillade between rival drug gangs during an exchange of more than 15 gunshots that sent many people scurrying for cover on Friday evening at a playground in the Castle Hill Houses in the Union Port section of the Bronx.

nytimes_articles.headline:
ROWING;
Harvard Dominates Yale After Many Crew Changes
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Harvard dominated Yale today by winning all three rowing races in the 128th renewal of America's oldest intercollegiate athletic event.

This year's Yale varsity, which finished ahead of Harvard in the Eastern Sprint Championships on May 9, was thought to have the best chance of any Eli crew of ending Harvard's current eight-year winning streak, but that did not happen today.

nytimes_articles.headline: Krone Winds Up First In More Ways Than 1
nytimes_articles.abstract: Julie Krone was eavesdropping yesterday and didn't like what she heard. She drew herself to her 4 feet 10 1/2 inches and, in that squeaky voice that makes 1,200-pound horses run so fast, admonished Scotty Shulhofer. "What year is this?" she said. "Sixty-something or '93?"   She was kidding, more or less. For Schulhofer had just admitted that he had once been against women jockeys.

nytimes_articles.headline: Irene M. Koch, Ronald Adelman
nytimes_articles.abstract: Irene Marci Koch, an associate at the New York law firm of Willkie Farr & Gallagher, was married last evening to Ronald Wolf Adelman, an associate at the law firm of Patterson, Belknap, Webb & Tyler. Rabbi Richard Jacobs performed the ceremony at the Fenway Golf Club in Scarsdale, N.Y.   Ms. Koch, 29, is keeping her name. She graduated cum laude from Cornell University. She and her husband received law degrees from Fordham University. Ms. Koch is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome S. Koch of Scarsdale. Her father is a first vice president, in Scarsdale, for Gruntal & Company, the investment firm. Her mother, Judith Koch, is a vice president at Dudley D. Doernberg Real Estate in Scarsdale.

nytimes_articles.abstract:
The book of my enemy has been remaindered
 And I am pleased.

nytimes_articles.headline: Lucretia Adymy, Robert Risoleo
nytimes_articles.abstract: Lucretia Marie Adymy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Adymy of Orchard Park, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert Samuel Risoleo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Risoleo of Pittsburgh. Msgr. George Brennan performed the ceremony at the Church of the Holy Family in Buffalo.

nytimes_articles.headline: Whale Watching
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor: The Q & A column on May 16 contained a request for information on whale watching, which was followed by a long list of ports, including the Okeanos Foundation sailings from Hampton Bays, L.I.   Two years ago my boyfriend and I went on a whale-watching trip with this organization after having read about it in The Times. We took Dramamine before boarding, anticipating that there might be some queasiness, but we were never so sick in our lives. More than 75 percent of the passengers were just as sick. Old people, young people and kids were vomiting profusely almost the entire time.

nytimes_articles.headline: Freemasons Begin to Lift the Veil of Arcana
nytimes_articles.abstract: After years of being known as a reclusive, secretive society, the American Freemasons have begun to open the door to the public a little. The reasons are simple: they have developed some important enemies and they are running out of members.   Because national membership has declined from 4.1 million in 1959 to an aging 2.4 million today, the fraternal order began a renewal campaign two years ago.

nytimes_articles.headline: Tribute to a 'Populist of the Highest Order'
nytimes_articles.abstract: WITH poetry, original dance compositions and emotional tributes, members of the world of modern dance recently honored the long and still active career of Bessie Schonberg, one of its revered leaders.   Gathered in a dance studio at Sarah Lawrence College here, the crowd of about 60 sometimes tearful alumni, dance professionals and academics watched as the studio -- in which Miss Schonberg often taught as the director of the college's dance department from 1938 to 1973 -- was officially named the Bessie Schonberg Dance Theater.

nytimes_articles.headline: Aspin Meets Russian in Bid to Take Ukraine's A-Arms
nytimes_articles.abstract: Stepping up the American campaign to persuade the Ukrainians to give up their nuclear weapons, Defense Secretary Les Aspin came here today to discuss with Russia a new plan to dismantle Ukraine's nuclear missiles and place their warheads under international supervision.    Mr. Aspin met with the Russian Defense Minister, Gen. Pavel S. Grachev. The plan is intended to resolve a Russian-Ukrainian dispute on how to deal with the warheads that would be removed from Ukraine's missiles if Ukraine gave up its nuclear arms.

nytimes_articles.headline: Cold Feet in the Senate
nytimes_articles.abstract: The weather outside the Capitol is warming up with the approach of summer. But inside some Senate Democrats are getting cold feet about serious political reform. The sticking point is public financing of elections. Unless President Clinton and Senate Democrats who understand the public's disgust at the present system now stand firm, a critical component of reform could be lost.   The issue will be joined in earnest this week when the Senate resumes debate on Mr. Clinton's proposed campaign finance reform. It's a promising bill that would curb reliance on special interests and foster greater competition by establishing a system of spending limits and partial public financing for House and Senate campaigns.

nytimes_articles.headline: 'Indie' Rock Settles Into the Executive Suite
nytimes_articles.abstract: Jim Dunbar doesn't come across as a typical music industry bigwig. Instead of a business suit, he's likely to wear worn-out jeans, a T-shirt and a black leather jacket to work. He doesn't talk numbers or profits, and he doesn't hype, but he tends to launch into long, elaborate yarns about how he was once suspended from his job as a disk jockey for not letting the D.J. after him onto the air. Mr. Dunbar's idea of a high-powered lunch spot is Prime Burger, a crazy old 40's-style diner in midtown Manhattan, where swinging table-trays are attached to the chair arms and red meat for two (including fries on the side) comes in at well under $20.    As an A & R (artists and repertory) executive at Columbia, Mr. Dunbar is responsible for recruiting hip, challenging and (it is hoped) potentially profitable young bands to the label. His biggest assets for the job, he says, are his long, stringy hair hanging down almost to his waist and his thick, uncombed beard. Grabbing a fistful of locks, he grins and says: "This is my coat and tie. I can walk into any club in the world and go backstage and start rapping with the band. They're not afraid of me, because I look like one of them."

nytimes_articles.headline: Commercial Property: Bryant Park; Once Anathema, Now a Midtown Marketing Tool
nytimes_articles.abstract: CONVENTIONAL wisdom says nobody is getting higher rents for commercial space today than they did a few years ago. But don't tell that to Tom Kelly.   Mr. Kelly is a senior vice president of Mountain Development Corporation, which owns the Beaux Arts, the landmarked office building at the southeast corner of 40th Street and Avenue of the Americas. Until a year or so ago, four of the building's 10 floors were empty and, at asking prices of about $19 a foot, tenants were barely nibbling.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Man Who Reinvented the Louvre
nytimes_articles.abstract: By common consent, "The Century of Titian" at the Grand Palais is just about the most beautiful exhibition of European Old Master paintings and drawings that ever was put together. There are two basic reasons for this. One is that in the context of Titian and his precursors, friends, rivals, emulators and successors -- among them, Giovanni Bellini, Giorgione, Tintoretto and Veronese -- the show includes a remarkably high percentage of what everyone most wants to see.   No less important is the fact that the Grand Palais show, which continues through June 14, has not been dictated by some satrap of the seminar. It is an unscripted encounter in which works of art never before brought together in such numbers are left free to sort themselves out.

nytimes_articles.headline: John F. Yang And Joyce Yang
nytimes_articles.abstract: Joyce Chuan-Chu Yang, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Steve S. Yang of Pleasantville, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Francis Yang, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George C. Yang of Hyattsville, Md. The Rev. Dr. Mark S. Anschutz, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at St. James's Church in New York.    Mrs. Yang, 31, is a senior analyst in the structured finance group at Moody's Investors Service in New York. She and her husband graduated from Cornell University, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa.

nytimes_articles.headline: Regina Godvin, Stephen de Gersdorff
nytimes_articles.abstract: Regina Marie Godvin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David L. Godvin of Rumson, N.J., was married there yesterday to Stephen Ogden de Gersdorff, a son of Carl de Gersdorff of New York and Susan Gilbertson of Rumson. The Rev. Francis G. Hilton performed the ceremony at the Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church.   Mrs. de Gersdorff is the marketing communications specialist at Philip Morris International Inc., in Rye Brook, N.Y. She graduated from Boston College. Her father is an investment banker in Rumson.

nytimes_articles.headline: On a Night Gone Wrong, Rivers Is What's Right
nytimes_articles.abstract: It was thrilling to see Doc Rivers hound Michael Jordan in the dying moments of the Knicks season here Friday night. And it was sad. Rivers wanted to give so much to win a championship for the Knicks, for himself. But by the end he just didn't have nearly enough to give.   On the night the Knicks expired, Rivers was everything that was ever right about the 1992-93, 60-victory Knicks. And wrong.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Quest to Conserve Electrical Power
nytimes_articles.abstract: It is unfortunate that "Lilco Ends a Homeowners' Rebate Program"  [ May 16 ]  further confuses a complicated issue. There are two central issues facing those of us active in the fields of energy analysis, conservation and demand-side management.  The first concerns are the quality, cost-effectiveness and long-term viability of utility demand-side management programs. The second is the methodology that the New York State Public Service Commission uses to allow Lilco and other New York State utilities to recover energy-conservation costs through the rate base. And while these two issues affect each other, it is important to make distinctions between the two.

nytimes_articles.headline: When All Roads Lead to Your Sofa
nytimes_articles.abstract: SUMMER is coming. It's in the air, on the street, in the loafers and in the hemlines. Summer is coming to Rome, and the prospect is terrifying, because when summer comes, so do visitors. I'm not talking about the Mom, Pop and old-fishing-buddy kind, but the kind who reincarnate dead acquaintanceships as true bondings once they discover your address is no longer a cobwebbed mailbox in some place even Indiana Jones wouldn't visit, but Rome, magical Rome, where the hotels are costly -- and doesn't old so-and-so live there now?   Since moving to Rome, I have discovered what seems to be the guiding principle of the world's floating population of unsolicited visitors: the popularity of the potential host rises in direct proportion to his or her proximity to the Pantheon.

nytimes_articles.headline: Summer Camp for Lovers
nytimes_articles.abstract:
WHERE OR WHEN
